answer_html: As \(t \to \infty\) we have that \(y(t) \to k.\)
hints_html: Plug in \(y_0 = \frac{k}{2}\) into the solution of Problem 4b. Remember that \(y_0 = \frac{k}{2}\) and use this to select the appropriate signs in the expression. Then take the limit as \(t \to \infty\).

hints_raw: Plug in <math> y_0 = \frac{k}{2} </math> into the solution of [http://wiki.ubc.ca/Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH103/April_2012/Question_4_%28b%29 Problem 4b].  Remember that <math> y_0 = \frac{k}{2} </math> and use this to select the appropriate signs in the expression.  Then take the limit as <math> t \to \infty </math>.
question: 4 (d)
sols_html:
Using similar reasoning as the previous problem,

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) &= \pm \sqrt{k^2 \pm |(k/2)^2-k^2| e^{-\lambda t^2}} \\ &= \pm \sqrt{k^2 \pm |-3/4| k^2 e^{-\lambda t^2}} \\ &= \pm k \sqrt{1 \pm 3/4 e^{-\lambda t^2}} \end{aligned}\]

When t=0, y(0)>0, so we need to take the positive branch outside the square root:

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) = + |k| \sqrt{1 \pm 3/4 e^{-\lambda t^2}} = k\sqrt{1 \pm 3/4 e^{-\lambda t^2}},\end{aligned}\]

again the last equality holding since k is positive. If we evaluate this at t=0, the positive branch gives \(y(0) = k \sqrt{1 + 3/4} = \sqrt{7}k/2\), which is wrong, since y(0)=y0=k/2. Hence this is the wrong branch. Indeed, the negative branch gives \(y(0) = k \sqrt{1 - 3/4} = k/2.\) Our answer is therefore

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) = k \sqrt{1 - 3/4 e^{-\lambda t^2}},\end{aligned}\]

As \(t \to \infty\) we have that \(y(t) \to k.\)
sols_raw:
Using similar reasoning as the previous problem,

:<math>
\begin{align}
y(t) & = \pm \sqrt{k^2 \pm  |(k/2)^2-k^2| e^{-\lambda  t^2}} \\
& = \pm \sqrt{k^2 \pm |-3/4| k^2 e^{-\lambda  t^2}} \\
& = \pm k \sqrt{1 \pm 3/4 e^{-\lambda  t^2}} 
\end{align}
</math>

When ''t''=0, ''y''(0)>0, so we need to take the positive branch outside the square root: 

:<math>
y(t) = + |k| \sqrt{1 \pm 3/4 e^{-\lambda  t^2}} = k\sqrt{1 \pm 3/4 e^{-\lambda  t^2}},
</math>

again the last equality holding since ''k'' is positive. If we evaluate this at ''t''=0, the positive branch gives <math>y(0) = k \sqrt{1 + 3/4}  = \sqrt{7}k/2</math>, which is wrong, since ''y''(0)=''y''<sub>0</sub>=''k''/2. Hence this is the wrong branch. Indeed, the negative branch  gives <math>y(0) = k \sqrt{1 - 3/4} = k/2.</math> Our answer is therefore

:<math>
y(t) = k \sqrt{1 - 3/4 e^{-\lambda  t^2}},
</math>

As <math>t \to \infty</math> we have that <math> y(t) \to k.</math>
statement_html:
Consider the differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt} = -\lambda t \left( \frac{y^2 - k^2}{y} \right),\end{aligned}\]

where \(\lambda\) is a positive constant, t \(\geq\) 0, k > 0, but y may be positive or negative. Suppose y(0) = y0.

Suppose y0 = k/2. Write the solution to the differential equation above in the form

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) = \cdots.\end{aligned}\]

What happens as \(t \to \infty\)?
statement_raw:
Consider the differential equation

:<math>
\frac{dy}{dt} = -\lambda t \left( \frac{y^2 - k^2}{y} \right),
</math>

where <math> \lambda </math> is a positive constant, ''t'' &ge; 0, ''k'' > 0, but ''y'' may be positive or negative. Suppose
''y''(0) = ''y''<sub>0</sub>.

Suppose ''y''<sub>0</sub> = ''k''/2. Write the solution to the differential equation above in the form

:<math> y(t) = \cdots.</math>

What happens as <math> t \to \infty </math>?
